entry.title: Combined summary - DarkWallet Best Practices
entry.summary: The DarkWallet Hackathon focused on discussing principles of decentralized Bitcoin usage with a focus on privacy, education, and security. Various measures were recommended, such as avoiding address re-use, implementing CoinJoin, using TOR, and allowing users to set fees. The article emphasized that wallet software should balance privacy protection with usability for effective adoption by users. Developers must ensure source-code and binary integrity using revision control systems such as git and PGP signatures. Multisig wallets are important to protect against spending without user knowledge, and wallet software should support some form of multi-factor protection for wallet funds.Payment protocol BIP70 was highlighted as essential to protect against spending without user knowledge, but its dependence on the certificate authority system is a concern that needs to be addressed. Wallet software should support paying funds to P2SH addresses and support BIP70. Additionally, the email thread discussed the debate surrounding per-commit signatures to ensure code integrity in Bitcoin development. Amir Taaki suggests that per-commit signatures are necessary for Bitcoin development due to the use of third-party platforms like GitHub. While Linus Torvalds advises against it, arguing that it is unnecessary and potentially weakens signatures.The article recommends using off-the-shelf identity systems like OpenPGP and SSL certificate authorities rather than introducing new ones vulnerable to MITM attacks. The article discusses various measures to enhance privacy, decentralization, security, and integrity of Bitcoin wallet software. It acknowledges the challenges of making PGP more user-friendly and calls for efforts to improve the user experience.
